references.text: Mason, see footnote 1

A possible physical explanation of this source has recently been pointed out by a physical model of a dislocation devised by J. S. Courtney-Pratt and D. Tabor. In this model a dislocation is represented by two sets of equally-spaced springs with magnets on the ends. One set is fixed and the other moves on. a carriage. By this means it can be demonstrated that the force causing the carriage to return to its equilibrium position is much larger if all the springs are equally spaced than if a discontinuity (dislocation) is introduced in the Position of one spring. W;hen one set of springs goes past the other, all the energy is not returned to the motion but sets up vibrations in the springs as one spring goes from a coupling to one reed to a coupling to the next. This represents a dissipation not as yet introduced into dislocation theory. If the dislocation is one cutting across energy boundaries (zig-zag dislocation) this mechanism introduces a dissipation proportional to the displacement.

references.text: The proof of a more general counterpart to this statement is given in the Appendix.

The proof may be effected as follows: The first tuning operation yields the condition B = 0, the second yields the condition BD*–AC* = 0 (see Appendix). From these results it is evident that either A = 0 or C = 0. The former represents a trivial solution. (See footnote 5.) Substituting these results in (14) and (15) yields b2 = (A/Δ)b4 and a2 = (D/Δ)b3.

Other types of impedance standards might also be employed for the purpose of the immediate discussion. The high quality fixed short has been specified in anticipation of the more general procedure to follow. The discussion might also be generalized to account for deviations of the short from the assumed ideal behavior; however this assumption involves only second order errors in the immediate application, and because of the additional complexity which would be introduced in the presentation, the results of this generalization will not be given.

Footnote 5 describes two procedures for adjusting Tx and Ty such that the ideal reflectometer response is achieved, and both methods are applicable to this problem. In the first method, however, the adjustment of Ty requires first the adjustment of Tx. In the present application, if the necessity for adjusting Tx is to be avoided, the adjustment of Ty must be effected through use of the sliding short as described.

The dissipationless joint includes, by definition, a lossless and uniform section of waveguide extending in both directions from the terminal surfaces and of sufficient length such that the higher modes excited by a discontinuity at these surfaces will be attenuated to a negligible value within the lossless region.

references.text: The Spearman rank correlation coefficient has been designed so that when two rankings are identical, the rank correlation coefficient has the value plus one; when one ranking is exactly the reverse of the other, the rank correlation coefficient is minus one. A Spearman rank correlation coefficient of 0.74 shows a fair degree of agreement between the two rankings. The probability of this amount of agreement occurring by chance, as determined by the student "t" test, is one in ten thousand.

references.text: In the literature these amplifiers have been referred to as "negative capacity," "negative input capacity," or "anticapacity" amplifiers. Since the method utilized is clearly the same as has been traditionally known as neutralization and since the term "negative capacity amplifier" may incorrectly imply that amplification takes place because of negative capacity (by analogy with negative resistance), we have felt it advisable to revert to the traditional name of neutralization in identifying these amplifiers.
